thread.title: NJSIAA officials express concern over enforcement of proposed bill
thread.title_full: NJSIAA officials express concern over enforcement of proposed bill

author: Matthew Stanmyre | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com
title: NJSIAA officials express concern over enforcement of proposed bill
text:
By Matthew Stanmyre | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com on October 14, 2015 2:05 PM View/Post Comments 
ROBBINSVILLE — New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association Executive Director Steve Timko said Wednesday the organization will “continue to work” with sponsors of a controversial bill slated to be introduced next month that aims to penalize athletes who repeat a grade in middle school to gain athletic advantage in high school. 
The bill would limit student athletes who repeat grades six, seven or eight — despite being academically on track — to three years or six consecutive semesters of athletic eligibility once they begin high school. The potential legislation — as currently written — would place the burden of enforcing the rule on the NJSIAA. 
Timko and other officials expressed concern over potential oversight for the bill. 
RELATED : Sen. Codey to push bill penalizing athletes who repeat grades for athletic edge 
“As it progresses we’ll continue to work with Sen. [Richard] Codey and the other sponsors,” Timko said. “I see where his issues are and I understand what they are. But at the same time being able to manage it might be difficult. We don’t have any jurisdiction over the middle school programs and a lot of those situations are there. Non-public schools could be another situation. As this thing continues to move forward hopefully he’ll be working with us and I think he will.” 
Paul Anzano, special counsel to the NJSIAA for legislative affairs, said the organization “would love to prohibit it or stop it or deter it, but with Codey’s proposal, enforcement becomes a question.” 
Coaches and recruiting analysts say athletes everywhere are repeating or “redshirting” in middle school in record numbers. The athletes who do it often grow bigger, stronger and faster, and become more polished athletes to better draw the attention of coaches and recruiters. Currently, there are no rules against athletes repeating a grade in middle school. 
NJSIAA attorney Steve Goodell said the organization already has protocol in place to deter redshirting at the high school level. A student-athlete is not eligible to compete as a high school senior if he or she turns 19 before Sept. 1 of that school year. And an athlete can only play sports for four consecutive years or eight consecutive semesters once they reach high school. 
RELATED : How to build a sports superstar in 2015: The engineering of 15-year-old Josh McKenzie 
“We share the concerns of the sponsor about redshirting,” Goodell said. “We have our own provisions against redshirting at the high school level. We generally don’t think that it’s good for a kid’s development. They shouldn’t be promoting sports over academics.” 
Anzano said reaction to the bill has been “mixed.” 
“It is inappropriate,” Anzano added. “But the public comments have been mixed.”
